data.title: Text keeps selecting on mouse movement
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Whenever I move the mouse in the editor, the text in the editor keeps on selecting.

**Note:** This issue only reproduces with the `atom-terminal-panel` package.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
1. Install the `atom-terminal-panel` package
1. Add Project Folder and add any folder
1. Open any file from the folder
1. Select some text using the mouse

**Expected behavior:** When the mouse button is release text stops being selected

**Actual behavior:** Mouse button is stuck and text keeps being selected on mouse movement

**Reproduces how often:** 10 out of 10 times.

### Versions
atom --version ==>
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm --version ==>
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

uname -a ==>
Darwin Apples-MacBook-Pro.local 16.7.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.7.0:
macOS Sierra Version 10.12.6
![atomscreenselectionissue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6063899/29265874-4c16027c-8100-11e7-942e-946fd142c0ad.gif)

data.title: GitHub for Mac stopped detecting changes on my repo after installing Atom and opening the repo as a project
data.body:
### Description

Have GitHub (GUI) for Mac, installed Atom and opened a project in Atom.
After that, when I tried to commit my changes using GitHub, none of the changes done appear on GitHub.
Not sure if the GitHub package of Atom is causing problems wit the GitHub app for Mac.
Trying to sync via the GitHub app says "Could not create status list".
Before installing Atom the app worked OK.

### Versions

Atom 1.19.0 x64
MacOS 10.12.6

data.title: Nested projects result in Atom opening files in wrong project window
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

A project which contains another project within a subdirectory can result in files being opened in the incorrect project window.

Given a main project at `/project`, and another project at `/project/subproject`. Upon opening a file from Finder, Atom doesn't open the file in the correct project window if one of the other project windows is already open.

This can result in a file at `/project/subproject/file.txt` being opened in the `/project` project window.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a new window in Atom, and add a directory as a project folder.
2. Repeat this step, adding a directory which is a subdirectory of the first.
3. Close the second project window.
3. In macOS Finder, open a file which lives in the subdirectory.

**Expected behavior:**

Atom opens the project window for the subdirectory project and opens the file.

**Actual behavior:**

Atom opens the file in the existing project window for the root directory project.

**Reproduces how often:**

Every time.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
OS      : macOS 10.12.3 

### Additional Information

Note that if you already have both project windows open, the problem does not appear to occur.

data.title: Native macOS tabs stopped working in Atom 1.19.0
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

After updating to 1.19.0, native macOS tabs stopped working. Whenever I press Shift-Command-N or ```atom .``` in the command line, it pops up a new window.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. On macOS, update Atom from 1.18.0 to 1.19.0.
2. With atom having at least one window already open, try opening a new window by Shift-Command-N, or typing ```atom .``` in Terminal.

**Expected behavior:** 
New windows appear as native macOS tabs. You can drag a tab out of the window if you want to have two windows side-by-side.

**Actual behavior:** 
A separate windows pops up every time you reopen a project. 

**Reproduces how often:** 
Every time, 100% of the time. The feature does not work any more. Downgrading to 1.18.0 brings the feature back.

### Versions

Atom 1.19.0 and macOS (10.12.6 and, I presume, all versions of macOS since Apple added support for native tabs).

### Additional Information

I have done some digging and was very surprised to find that this feature was not actually intended or supported by Atom maintainers. 

Either way, the feature has always "just worked". I'm way too used to this behavior by now. It's a useful feature and there's no reason to get rid of it.

data.title: Closing the tab using the mousewheel on any file change causes Atom to crash
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

-   [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    -   Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: <http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode>
    -   Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: <http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/>
    -   Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: <https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq>
    -   Checked that your issue isn't already filed: <https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom>
    -   Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: <https://atom.io/packages>

### Description

Generally, closing the tabs by clicking the mousewheel doesn't have any issues at all **as long as the tabs being closed are of files that have already been saved**. But if the file is **not** saved, Atom crashes right after displaying the dialog box that asks the user whether to save or discard the changes made.

### Steps to Reproduce

The three examples enumerated below -- _renaming_, _modifying_, and _deleting a file_, all have the same end result. A dialog box will appear and Atom hangs and crashes.

#### Renaming a file

1.  Create a new file.

```sh
touch test.sh
```

2.  Open file in Atom using `atom --safe`.
3.  Add text.

```sh
#!/usr/bin/env bash
echo "Hello World!"
```

4.  Save the file but **leave the tab open**.
5.  In the terminal, do:

```sh
mv test.sh hello.sh
```

Atom's tab will display a dot that indicates that a change has occurred, which in this case is the **filename**. 

6.  Close the tab using your **mousewheel**. A dialog box would open asking if you would like to save or discard the changes.

#### Modifying a file

1.  Create a new file.

```sh
touch test.txt
```

2.  Open file in Atom using `atom --safe`.
3.  Add text.

```txt
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. 
```

4.  Save the file but **leave the tab open**.
5.  Delete the contents and replace it with.

```txt
The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog.
```

Atom's tab will display a dot that indicates that a change has occurred, which in this case is the **content**.

6.  Close the tab using your **mousewheel**. A dialog box would open asking if you would like to save or discard the changes.

#### Deleting a file

1.  Open Atom using `atom --safe`.
2.  Open `test.txt` from the previous example.
3.  In the terminal, do:

```sh
rm test.txt
```

Atom's tab will display a dot that indicates that a change has occurred, which in this case is the file's **existence**.

4.  Close the tab using your **mousewheel**. A dialog box would open asking if you would like to save or discard the changes.

**Expected behavior:** 
Upon using the mousewheel to close the tab **_(for modified, renamed, or deleted files)_** a dialog box would appear and ask if the user would like to save or discard without hanging/crashing.

**Actual behavior:**
Getting the dialog box below only appears after opening a terminal and doing `killall atom` as Atom hangs and no longer responds to any user input and I'm also unable to do anything unless I do so. Clicking or right-clicking anywhere for that matter is futile (I'm using dual screens).

The other options I have would be `ctrl + alt + backspace` to restart X11 and `alt + sysrq + b` to force reboot.

[![Screenshot_from_2017-08-13_15-15-25.png](https://s26.postimg.org/dq9uyuxvt/Screenshot_from_2017-08-13_15-15-25.png)](https://postimg.org/image/wvd48mcjp/)

**Reproduces how often:**
99.9% in `atom --safe` mode

### Versions

-   `atom --version` output:

```sh
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
```

-   `apm --version` output:

```sh
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

-   OS / OS Version:

```sh
Linux Mint 18.2
```

### Additional Information

```sh
Kernel: 4.8.0-58-generic x86_64 (64 bit gcc: 5.4.0)
Desktop: Cinnamon 3.4.6 (Gtk 3.18.9-1ubuntu3.3)
CPU: Quad core Intel Core i7-4770S
GPU: NVIDIA GK104 [GeForce GTX 760]
Memory: 3244MiB / 11954MiB
```

`node -v` output:
```sh
v8.2.1
```

`npm -v` output:
```sh
5.3.0
```

I have experienced this issue with Atom 1.18.0 as well but I ~~ignored~~ didn't report it as I assumed that the upcoming iteration 1.19.0 (at that time) may or will address this issue.

Please let me know if there's anything else I can do _(e.g., terminal output that you might need)_ to help you in figuring out how to debug or fix this issue.

data.title: Can't delete multiple files from tree view
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

If you select multiple files in tree view and attempt to delete them, it will change the selection to a single file and only delete that 1 file.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Select multiple files in tree view
2. Right click on files, select 'Delete'

Here's a gif:
![files](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2279289/29254030-14eee152-8041-11e7-9631-6782c2d26ccd.gif)

**Expected behavior:**

All the selected files get deleted.

**Actual behavior:**

Only a single file gets deleted.

**Reproduces how often:**

100% reproducible.

### Versions

```
MacBook-Pro:Desktop atetelman$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0
MacBook-Pro:Desktop atetelman$ apm --version
apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0
MacBook-Pro:Desktop atetelman$ uname -mprsv
Darwin 16.7.0 Darwin Kernel Version 16.7.0: Thu Jun 15 17:36:27 PDT 2017; root:xnu-3789.70.16~2/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64 i386
MacBook-Pro:Desktop atetelman$
```

data.title: Fix IME composition preview for new editors
data.body:
Composition checkpoints are actually *numbers*, and the first checkpoint starts at `0`, which was previously being detected as falsy. The fix is to null check the composition checkpoint explicitly.

/cc @Ben3eeE @as-cii

data.title: 1.19 pixelRectForScreenRange regression
data.body:
### Description

TextEditorElement's pixelRectForScreenRange is returning incorrect values. 

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Perform a selection that spans 2 or more lines like in the below screenshot:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5797698/29252304-5f648804-8032-11e7-9318-840ce47cc369.png)
2. Run the below code snippet which uses pixelRectForScreenRange:
```
var editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor();
var screenRange= editor.getSelections()[0].getScreenRange();
atom.views.getView(editor).pixelRectForScreenRange(screenRange);
```

**Expected behavior:** I would expect the left value to be 0 and the width value to be meaningful. In Atom v1.18, they are correct.

**Actual behavior:** In Atom v1.19, left is not 0 and width is a negative number.

### Versions

Works in v1.18 - broken in v1.19. All OS.

data.title: [FEATURE REQUEST] Expose option to allow / disallow updates of Packages.
data.body:
### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * ~~Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/~~ _not a bug_ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description [Description of the issue] ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open Atom, close all open panes 2. Open development console 3. Open Settings >> Updates (do not trigger button for getting updates) 4. Close Atom 5. Disconnect from internet 6. Open Atom 5. Observe messages in console (2) and settings (3) (Reopen if required) 6. Reload Atom by `ctrl-shift-f5' 7. Observe messages in console (2) and settings (3) 8. Re-do (6) and (7). **Expected behaviour:** Reload of Packages should not update so soon after being updated a short time earlier. If the internet connection is not there, the message should not be an ERROR but rather a WARNING. Suggest to have the user selectable option to not have the system update the packages. This option is available for the core. **Actual behaviour:** [What actually happens] Each time Atom is reloaded, the package updating is triggered. An ERROR is triggered if the connection is not made, influencing start-up times. **Reproduces how often:** Always ### Versions Atom V1.19 under Windows7 SP1 ### Additional Information (Full Description) SUBJECT: [FEATURE REQUEST] Expose option to allow / disallow updates of Packages. Good day. May this message find you well. #### Symptoms The behaviour is observed Atom V1.19 under Windows7 SP1. Each time Atom is reloaded (opening Atom | command: `reload()` | shortcut: `ctrl-shift-f5`) the update service for the Packages is triggered. This happens _each_ time a reload occurs, regardless of time gone by since the last trigger. #### Problem The impact of triggering the `update of Packages` is most prominently observed when regular `reload()` is done in the process of developing customizations for Atom. This behaviour causes extended start-up time especially when working offline from the internet. Also consumption of internet data is a concern for those who use expensive (capped) mobile data as internet source. Some more details can be found on.. [Atom community discussion](https://discuss.atom.io/t/how-to-prevent-atom-to-update-packages-at-each-reload/45638) The mechanism of the `update of Packages` is here: [Link to code](https://github.com/atom/settings-view/blob/ea7f18e089fcd4fbcb549aa04dd963437e26f2c0/lib/main.coffee#L70) #### Suggestions 1. Record the time of last `update of Packages`. Do not execute the update if the elapsed time is too short. 2. Expose the option as a setting to prevent the `update of Packages` to occur. This is the same concept as "Automatic Update" option in the "Core Settings". ![Automatic Updates only applied for CORE](https://cdn-business.discourse.org/uploads/github_atom/original/3X/1/0/10027aa2523229818dcc9058781ce9ca212606c7.png) 3. Downgrade the message from ERROR to WARNING that tells the user that an internet connection could not be made. ![ERROR: having no internet connection is a sin](https://cdn-business.discourse.org/uploads/github_atom/original/3X/c/e/ce0432891c088e6a6b764fcc636f4c754a926092.png) Best regards,
  dP

data.title: Block decoration scrolls instead of registering mouse clicks
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When interacting with a block decoration near the bottom of the text editor, the decoration scrolls up instead of registering the click event:

![scroll](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13285808/29250800-3ed964f8-8049-11e7-8ceb-97c405851c0b.gif)


This issue came up with the [Hydrogen](https://github.com/nteract/hydrogen) package which uses block decorations to display interactive outputs with "clickable" elements. But this is a general problem also present in safe mode.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file with at least 10 to 20 lines of code
2. Run the following code in the dev tools:
```js
function createBlock(row) {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  const item = document.createElement("span");
  item.innerText = "[block decoration]\n".repeat(10);
  const button = document.createElement("button");
  button.innerText = "Click me!"
  button.addEventListener('click', () => {
    alert("CLICK!")
  });
  div.appendChild(item);
  div.appendChild(button);
  const editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor();
  const marker = editor.markBufferPosition([row, 0]);
  editor.decorateMarker(marker, { type: "block", item: div });
}

createBlock(8)
```
3. Scroll the block decoration to the bottom of the text editor and try to click the button.

**Expected behavior:** The button click is registered and a alert box pops up.

**Actual behavior:** The editor scrolls up and the click isn't registered. A second click on the button is necessary to show the pop up.

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

macOS 10.12.6:
- Atom 1.20.0-beta0
- Atom 1.19.0

    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * [x] Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * [x] Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Quickly input enter and quickly delete enter, atom crashed.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Install my package [backspace-until-not-whitespace](https://atom.io/packages/backspace-until-not-whitespace).

2. Open a file.
3. Write a lines with a tab at beginning like this:
```
    aaaa
```
4. Save the file (e.g. "test.html")
5. Move the cursor to the end of line.
6. Press enter to create a new line.
7. Quickly press backspace to delete the new line.
8. Repeat step5 and step6 for about two or three times.

![packagetc480](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2340296/29246905-c19b49c6-8038-11e7-939f-20b06156881e.gif)


![imagexxx](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2340296/29246903-b835fb24-8038-11e7-815e-47b04718f37b.png)


**Expected behavior:** Not crash.

**Actual behavior:** Atom crashed.

**Reproduces how often:** About over 90%.

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

apm  1.18.2
npm  3.10.10
node 6.9.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.11.0

OS: macOS Sierra Version 10.12.6

### Additional Information
I have disabled all the other community packages, and even disabled language-html and language-xml, only left my package as mentioned in step1.

data.title: Untargetable buttons in save changes dialogue
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Closing a file with modifications prompts for "file has changes, do you want to save them?". But the UI is untargetable. Clicking with the mouse has no effect. Using the keyboard on the other hand works just fine.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. Create a new tab (file)
3. Type anything
4. Attempt to close the tab via middle click OR clicking the close X button on the tab
5. You are now unable to click any of the buttons on the dialogue window

**Expected behavior:** I can click on Save | Cancel | Don't Save buttons

**Actual behavior:** Clicking does not work in any of the 3 buttons

**Reproduces how often:** 100% of the time

### Versions

Atom    : 1.20.0-beta1
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

Linux localhost.localdomain 3.10.0-514.2.2.el7.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Dec 6 23:06:41 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

CentOS Linux release 7.3.1611 (Core)

xfce4-panel 4.12.0 (Xfce 4.12)

VirtualBox 5.1.22r115126

### Additional Information

- Keyboard seems to work fine
- Screenshot of the Dialogue window in question: https://i.imgur.com/2GMYT5N.png
- Other dialogues seem to work fine (open file, save as, etc)
- WIndows 10 64bit works just fine
- This issue occurs regardless of the type of tab open (existing file, untitled buffer, etc)
- Using Alt+F4 to close the tab OR right click "close tab" functions correctly

data.title: Add accelerator indicators to context menus
data.body: Electron allows us to pass an "accelerator" property for each menu item, which is renders to the right of the menu item. We were already adding these for the application level menus. This pull request adds the accelerator property to regular context menu items, which should make it easier for people to discover/recall key mappings for actions which they usually take via a context menu. ### Before ### After

data.title: No formatting after 1000th character in a line
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In files with very long lines, Atom stops formatting after a specific number of characters. I counted and the number is 1000. This means if I have a line in for example XML-format that is 1008 characters long, the 8 last characters will not be formatted (colored in this case). I toggled between languages and the result is the same, no formatting after the 1000th character.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a file.
2. Add a line with more than 1000 characters

**Expected behavior:** I expected the characters after the 1000th to be formatted as well, allowing me to have long lines in Atom.

**Actual behavior:** After the 1000th characteer, all characters are grey, no color (i.e. not formatted)

**Reproduces how often:** 100%, every time

### Versions

Atom    : 1.19.0
Electron: 1.6.9
Chrome  : 56.0.2924.87
Node    : 7.4.0

OS: Windows 10 Pro Version 1703

### Additional Information
Here an image of the bug:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10940539/29241175-f8645566-7f74-11e7-9bc2-f6e74f2d6167.png)

data.title: Don't throw an error when setting an incredibly small `lineHeight`
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15111.

Instead, if the measured line height equals 0, default it to 1 so that the editor component doesn't start computing `NaN` or `Infinity` values due to e.g. dividing by 0. The result will still be illegible, but we won't throw weird error messages like `RangeError: Invalid array length`, as in the referenced issue.

We should probably consider sanitizing line heights smaller than a certain threshold, but that's non trivial because line height is expressed as a multiplier of the font size. Also, users may style the `line-height` property via CSS, which may still throw errors when using small values.

@Ben3eeE @ungb: can you help me confirm this fixes the issue above? I can't reproduce it anymore, but it might be good to be 100% sure.

/cc: @nathansobo

data.title: Fix measuring lines in presence of pending autoscroll requests
data.body:
Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/15168.

Calling `pixelPositionForScreenPosition` was sometimes throwing an error indicating that the requested position was not rendered and that, as such, could not be measured.

This was caused by trying to measure a line that was visible at the moment of the call while also having a pending autoscroll request that would cause that line to go off-screen. Due to how the code was structured, we would mistakenly detect that line as visible, autoscroll to a different location, re-render a different region of the buffer and then try to measure the now invisible line.

This commit fixes this issue by restructuring and simplifying the logic for rendering invisible lines in order to measure them. Now, every line for which a measurement has been requested is stored in a `linesToMeasure` map. During the first phase of the update process (after honoring autoscroll requests), we detect which of these lines are currently visible and if some of them are not, we store them into the `extraRenderedScreenLines` map, which is then used to render lines that are invisible but need measurement.

@Ben3eeE @ungb: I am unable to reproduce the issue after this pull-request. Can you help me ensure this fixes all the reports we've got for this issue so far? They seem to be generated by slightly different reproduction steps, although I think they can all be traced back to the root cause described above.

/cc: @nathansobo for 👀

data.title: No elevation of privilege prompt when attempting to edit files owned by root
data.body:
Prior to v1.19, when attempting to save over a file that is owned by root on macOS, Atom would prompt for elevated permissions. It doesn't any longer and just gives an error.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Launch Atom with `atom --safe /etc/profile`
1. Type `# testtesttest` and press <kbd>Enter</kbd> on the first line of the file
1. Save the file with <kbd>Cmd+S</kbd>

**Expected:** Dialog comes up asking for privilege elevation
**Actual:** Permission denied notification

data.title: Suppress composition events default prevented on previous keydown
data.body:
Fixes #15189

It seems like Chrome 56 has a regression that causes `compositionstart` and `compositionupdate` events to still be fired even if `preventDefault` is called on the original `keydown` event. This PR introduces a workaround that suppresses handling of these events if `defaultPrevented` is true on the most recent `keydown` event.

/cc @Ben3eeE @ungb
